Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply detailed with deep lines marking clypeus, prothorax and elytra; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside decorated with falcon to right wearing the red crown, standing on a neb-basket sign, with sun-disc above its back; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; longitudinally pierced; pale green glaze now mostly gone; core cream; surface quite abraded.
Curator's comments: Falcon, sometimes with a flail or wearing a crown like here, is a recurring motif for various compositions found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie noted four scarabs with the same motif as this scarab (published in Petrie 1886, pl. 37, no. 57). It belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A140-148, see especially A141 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 57)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98, Type XXVIII A141)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.040) (phase 3)
